What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Knowledge of Multi-Variable and vector calculus.

Calculus in 3 dimensions is basically what this course is about. Everything and anything in Math 115 but now extrapolated to 3 dimensions. I learned how to analyze and carry out operations on multivariable functions.
I learned the topics of multivariable calculus -- partial differentiation, multiple integrals, line and surface integrals, etc.
I robust understanding of multivariable calculus theorems and techniques. It is the next step of the calculus sequence, and coming out of AP BC in high school, it was a clear continuation
This was a good overview of multivariable calculus and three dimensional graphs.
How to visualize and evaluate the behaviors and calculus characteristics of 3D surfaces.
I learned multivariable calculus concepts and enhanced my ability to problem-solve.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Clearly taught, with engaging psets and fair exams. No improvements necessary in my opinion.

The course was great in general -- the instructor that I had was extremely clear and engaged with students. The pre-class videos were very helpful in learning the material. The p-sets and exams were doable. The one way that it could be improved would be by providing answer keys to the p-sets and exams after they are due so that we can confirm the correct processes and answers while using them to study for the next exam.
Overall it was very good. The pre-class lectures and videos were helpful and class, especially with Miki, was really great for understanding the basics, explanations, and harder applications.
I feel like there should be more feedback on Psets. The current level is sort of vague and didn't help me understand where I went wrong.

Strengths: the format of pre-class videos and in-class concept review and breakout room problem-solving was extremely effective; Weaknesses: sometimes the PSETs were quite long and, in combination with the pre-class videos, could take up a lot of time

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Virtual lectures with Miki were really good, and she made great use of zoom tools (polls, raise hand, etc.) to keep students engaged.
The pre-class videos worked very well, though sometimes the graded quizzes were a bit stressful. The structure of class sessions, with a mix of polls, breakout rooms, etc., was great.
It was all very good. There was a reasonable amount of pre-class work and it all directly impacted what we were doing in class.
I think this course was well-suited to virtual learning.
The pre-class videos, virtual peer tutoring sessions, and utilization of breakout rooms during lecture were all very effective.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This class provides a great foundation in multi-variable calculus, and is overall very engaging and well taught for students who like math.
Definitely if you want a strong and complete grounding in calculus.

Yes, if you can take the course with Miki, it's incredibly interesting and not nearly as bad as its reputation makes it seem. The topics are genuinely fascinating, and Miki explains everything so clearly and makes class sessions enjoyable. Exams were very fair, and while the p-sets were lengthy and included quite a bit of computation, the peer tutors are helpful.

If you enjoyed high school math and need a QR credit, this is a very good choice for another similar math class. It did, however, convince me to take more high level proof based math, but this class does not teach those skills. I also think that the course depends a lot on who leads your section, so shop it and make sure that you will enjoy learning from them and their teaching style matches how you best learn math.
I would recommend this course. Even though it was required for me, I still think it has a lot of interesting content, and I would have taken it even without the requirement.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in furthering their math education.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded lectures on the material with a live lecture focused on reviewing the recorded lectures and solving interactive problems.
Pre-class recorded videos and quizzes to be completed asynchronously
In-person class with pre-class lectures.
